hedline.hl1: Campaign to Use E-Mail To Promote Youth Vote

abstract.p: Rock the Vote plans to work with several large media partners to use e-mail messages to encourage voters ages 18 to 24 to vote; media taking part include ABC, Alta Vista, MTV and Sony Corp's Sony.com Web site (S)

block.p: An elaborate effort to use e-mail messages to encourage voters ages 18 to 24 to turn out in November gets under way today from an organization named Rock the Vote, assisted by several large media partners.

The media taking part include ABC, part of the Walt Disney Company; Alta Vista; the World Wide Web site of Entertainment Weekly magazine, part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc.; MTV, owned by Viacom; and the Sony.com Web site of the Sony Corporation of America. An estimated 10 million e-mail messages will be sent out, centered on issues like the death penalty, same-sex marriages and hate crimes.

An elaborate effort to use e-mail messages to encourage voters ages 18 to 24 to turn out in November gets under way today from an organization named Rock the Vote, assisted by several large media partners.

The media taking part include ABC, part of the Walt Disney Company; Alta Vista; the World Wide Web site of Entertainment Weekly magazine, part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc.; MTV, owned by Viacom; and the Sony.com Web site of the Sony Corporation of America. An estimated 10 million e-mail messages will be sent out, centered on issues like the death penalty, same-sex marriages and hate crimes.

''There's the opportunity to provoke people a bit,'' said Robin Raj, partner and creative director at Collaborate in San Francisco, the agency that developed the idea for the campaign. The participating Web sites will post animated commercials and streaming-video versions of TV spots.

Pandemonium and Western Images, both in San Francisco, are handling technological aspects of the campaign. The campaign is co-sponsored by Choose or Lose, MTV's longtime effort to encourage younger voters.
